importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the January 6 Capitol riot, during which Christopher Moynihan participated in the attack, is central to understanding the context of his conviction and subsequent pardon.

The current date of the article indicates a resurgence of attention to former Capitol rioters, especially those who were pardoned, highlighting ongoing concerns about violent extremism and threats to democratic institutions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from 2021 to 2025 captures the evolution of legal and political responses to Capitol rioters, including the pardon wave under Trump and the subsequent re-arrest of some individuals for new threats.

keyTakeAways: Christopher P. Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was pardoned by President Donald Trump in January 2025 after being convicted for his role in the January 6, 2021, Capitol attack.
Moynihan is now charged with making a terroristic threat against House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, specifically threatening to kill him in a text message.
The threat, which included statements like 'I will kill him for the future' and 'must be eliminated', has prompted swift action from law enforcement and political leaders.

The case underscores a broader concern about the re-emergence of violent extremism and the dangers posed by individuals who were previously pardoned for their actions during politically charged events.
New York State Police and the FBI were involved in detecting and investigating the threat, which was reported on Saturday and led to Moynihan's arrest on Sunday.
House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries publicly condemned the threat, emphasizing that violence against elected officials is unacceptable and should be prosecuted.
Dutchess County District Attorney Anthony Parisi stated the case is under legal review for sufficiency, signaling that the charges may be challenged in court.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher P. Moynihan, a 34-year-old man formerly convicted of participating in the January 6, 2021, Capitol riot and pardoned by President Donald Trump, has been arrested on a charge of making a terroristic threat against House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. According to a police report, Moynihan sent a text message threatening to kill Jeffries, stating 'I will kill him for the future' and that Jeffries 'must be eliminated.' The threat was reported to law enforcement by an FBI task force and led to Moynihan's arraignment in Dutchess County, New York. The case has prompted public concern over the safety of elected officials and the implications of pardoning violent offenders. Legal experts and political leaders, including House Speaker Mike Johnson and District Attorney Anthony Parisi, have condemned the threat, with Parisi stating the case is under review for legal sufficiency. This incident highlights ongoing tensions between executive pardons and public safety, as well as the persistent threat of political violence in U.S. democratic institutions.
title: Man Pardoned After Storming Capitol Is Charged with Threatening to Kill Hakeem Jeffries
